The late British sculptor Henry Moore inspired every aspect of this collection , from structured designs to a contoured beauty look and the set in Makers House. Burberry partnered with the Henry Moore Foundation for this show, celebrating the organizationâ€™s 40th anniversary and Mooreâ€™s work.

Seventy-nine looks walked past Mooreâ€™s sculptures lining the runway, with the artistâ€™s works informing the collectionâ€™s shapes and neutral palette â€” in white, ivory, navy, and gray fabrics. An ivory jacket and black boots opened the show, followed by ruffled white shirts and blue shirt dresses, cutout beige knit sweaters, and one-shouldered dresses with trench coats.
Photo: Daniel Leal-Olivas/AFP/Getty Images Like last season, there were unisex designs â€” both male and female models wore shirts embellished with frills and lace. A dress and a few menâ€™s shirts were printed with images of Mooreâ€™s sculptures.
